column2: Kathina Q&A with the Chithurst Community
Ajahn Pasanno spent Kaṭhina weekend at Chithurst and hosted two Q&A sessions.

column6: Session title
Text
After more than 50 years, is the practice getting easier?
Could you offer some reflections on experiencing mind as mind in the Noble Eightfold Path?
Chanting Book p. 97.
MN 10.34: Mindfulness of mind.
Does this relate to Luang Por Dune's reformulation of the Four Noble Truths where it says, 'The mind seeing the mind?'
Gifts He Left Behind p. 3.
An inward-staying unentangled knowing.|Upasikā Kee Nanayon
Could you speak about the practice of being mindful of craving and allowing it to pass?
If we don't understand the obstacle, we can't be free from it.
You've got to be really careful because the mind is a liar and a cheat.|Ajahn Chah
What practice would you recommend if you are too serious with your thinking?

It seems like I'm using physical tension to block out emotion. When I try to put my attention on it, the mind goes blank or starts thinking about work. I don't know what I'm avoiding. Any suggestions?
How did you learn Pāli syntax?
The Second Noble Truth, sumudaya—do you know it as arising of suffering or origin of suffering or does it matter?
SN 56.11.4: Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta ([Chanting book translation](Chanting Book V2 p. 4)): "ever seeking fresh delight."
The Buddha had a quality of fearlessness. How can we understand fearlessness?
The core of fearlessness is not having a self, an I, a me, a mine that it's trying to protect.
Could you say something about the name-and-form step in Dependent Origination?
MN 43.9: Conjoined not disjoined.
How do we recognize when we're being taken advantage of when we're trying to offer compassion? How do we draw a line to maintain our compassion without it impeding?
The qualities of the Buddha: wisdom, compassion, purity.
Chanting Book p. 3: Homage to the Buddha.
A person asks the same question four times.

Luang Por Sumedho describes sati-sampajañña as intuitive awareness. But contemplating the four aspects of sampajañña (purpose, suitability, etc.) engages the logical, thinking mind. If these arise intuitively, it's wonderful, but to cultivate them, I think a lot.
When someone opens up about issues or something difficult they are dealing with, when should one just listen and when should one say something that might help?
How does the practice of patience fit into the Noble Eightfold Path? How is patience the incinerator of defilements?
Ovāda Pātimokkha: Dhp 183-185 ([Chanting book translation](Chanting Book p. 79)).

Sometimes we hear that with practice, some qualities change, but other qualities don't change very much over a long time of practice. When I read certain biographies [of Buddhist teachers], it seems like certain rough qualities can remain even though the mind is pure. How to know the difference in oneself and others?
{teachers} describes the personality of great teachers he has met.
The arahant disciples of the Buddha were able to free their minds, but they all had different personalities.
SN 14.15 Caṅkama Sutta: Monks with different personalities gather around the great disciples.
Ajahn Pasanno mentions the similarly-themed Cūḷagosiṅga Sutta (MN 31) by name, but describes the content of the Caṅkama Sutta.
Is it ever acceptable to put a life out of suffering, for example when it's dying and suffering slowly?
Ajahn Pasanno and others look after a Brahma bull that was attacked by a tiger until it dies.
What does letting go feel like?
Is renunciation like surrender?
You let go a little, you get a little peace. You let go a lot, and you get a lot peace. Let go completely, and you get complete peace.|Ajahn Chah
Can renunciation be practiced in three aspects: material, speech and mind?
Luang Por Chah's teaching, "Not go forward, not go backward, not stand still;" is this like empty?
